ms.ipp.iterable.tree

Interface Tree<F>

  • Type Parameters:
    F - The superclass that Tree's immediate children must extend. The children's children are not required to be of type F.
    All Superinterfaces:
    BiIterable<java.lang.String,F>, java.lang.Iterable<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.String,F>>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractTree, DelegatingTree, StdMultiTree, StdTree, SyntheticTree

    public interface Tree<F>
extends BiIterable<java.lang.String,F>
    The API for all Tree-like structures. Its main features are:
  • The iterative structure which offers several methods for traversing the Tree's immediate children, such as #members(), iterator(..).
  • The associative structure allowing to effectively locate and manipulate members by their names, e.g., doPeek(..), doSet(..), doDelete(..).
  • The recursive structure, in the sense that an element is recognised to potentially have children if it implements the interface Tree. The recursive structure is compatible with both the iterative and the associative structures. More precisely, there is a collection of methods, such as recursive() which allow traversing over the entire Tree structure, including its children, the children's children, etc. On top of that, there are methods, such as peek(..), get(..), set(..), delete(..), for retrieving, setting or deleting elements by their full paths within the recursive structure (rather than just their names as elements of the Tree). How these paths are interpreted depends on the PathManipulator that the Tree is equipped with. All iterators and iterables are fully compatible with the methods in the class Iterables.
Author:
mykhailo.saienko

      • getBaseClass

      • setUpdater

        <T extends F> void setUpdater(java.lang.Class<T> type,
                              java.util.function.BiConsumer<T,T> updater)
        Sets an updater for a given type. If set(..) or doSet(..) are called and there is an updater for the passed type, it is called immediately before a new value replaces the old one. In this case, the old value is passed as the first and the new value - as the second parameter. WARNING: The updater assumes that the old value is of the same type as the new value. If this cannot be ensured, the affected set and doSet methods exhibit undefined behaviour.
        Parameters:
        type - the type for which a given updater must be called
        updater - a new updater or null in order to remove the updater

      • doSet

        <T> T doSet(java.lang.String name,
            T value,
            java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
        Sets a member with a given name to a given value. If the member with a given path cannot be found, reset or added, null is returned.
        Parameters:
        path -
        value - a new value to set for a given path. Must not be null.
        clazz -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - is value is null.

      • doDelete

        default void doDelete(java.lang.String name)
        Equivalent to doDelete(name, null).
        Parameters:
        name -

      • doDelete

        void doDelete(java.lang.String name,
              java.lang.Object value)
        The results depend on the content of the parameter value:
      • If value is not null, deletes all children with a given name which are equal to a given value.
      • If the value is null and the path identifies the child, it is deleted.
      • Otherwise, the result is undefined.
Parameters:
path -
value -

  • set

    <T> T set(java.lang.String path,
          T value,
          java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
    Sets a member with a given path to a given value. If the path is not simple, the search is carried recursively. If the member with the path cannot be found, reset or added, null is returned.
    Parameters:
    path -
    value - a new value to set for a given path. Must not be null.
    clazz -
    Returns:
    Throws:
    java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - is value is null.

    default void delete(java.lang.String path)
    Equivalent to: delete(path, null).
    Parameters:
    path -

  • delete

    void delete(java.lang.String path,
            java.lang.Object value)
    The results depend on the content of the parameter value:
  • If value is not null, recursively deletes all elements with a given path which are equal to a given value.
  • If the value is null and the path identifies the element, this element is deleted.
  • Otherwise, the result is undefined.
    Parameters:
    path -
    value -

  • peek

    <T> T peek(java.lang.String path,
           java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
    Retrieves a member with a given path and which is of a given type. If the path is not simple, the search is carried recursively. If there is no such member, returns null.
    Parameters:
    path -
    Returns:

  • get

    default <T> T get(java.lang.String path,
                  java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
    Retrieves an element with a given path and which is of a given type. If the path is not simple, the search is carried recursively. In contrast to peek(String, Class), if there is no such member, throws an IllegalArgumentException.
    Parameters:
    path -
    Returns:

    default <T> BiIterable<java.lang.String,T> recursive(java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
    Creates and returns a BiIterable which traverses all elements of a given type. This includes non-leaves if they are subclasses of T.
